Award.AbstractNarration:
The Sixth Ahlfors-Bers Colloquium will take place at Yale University on October 23-26, 2014. It is the latest of a triennial sequence of meetings focusing on the aspects of analysis, geometry, and partial differential equations originally explored by Lars Ahlfors and Lipman Bers and leading to a robust modern theory with ramifications and connections to many other fields, including dynamics, topology, mathematical physics and number theory. The field is characterized today by an interaction between analytic methods, using the tools of classical calculus and its generalizations, combinatorial ideas in which diagrammatic patterns are built and studied, and topology in which one studies flexible spaces and their deformations. The recent solution of a number of guiding problems and the corresponding introduction of new methods promise that the conference will be vibrant and forward looking. The organizers plan to attract and support early-career mathematicians and under-represented minorities, and hope that the resulting interactions and new connections will reverberate long after the conference is over.

Ten plenary speakers will discuss recent results in dynamics of rational maps, dynamics of interval exchanges, Teichmuller theory, harmonic analysis, the structure of automorphism groups, hyperbolic geometry, probability and Schramm-Loewner evolution, and others. Parallel sessions with contributed talks will be held broadly in these areas, where the conference organizers anticipate about 50 speakers. The conference website can be found at
https://sites.google.com/site/ahlforsberscolloquium/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Ahlfors-Bers Colloquium is a continuing series of meetings celebrating the mathematical heritage of Lars Ahlfors and Lipman Bers. The core of this legacy developed from their original work in the fields of geometric function theory, quasiconformal deformation theory, hyperbolic manifolds, and partial differential equations. However, their research has impacted and created interactions with many other fields, such as algebraic geometry, mathematical physics, stochastic calculus, dynamics, geometric group theory, topology, number theory and complex dynamics. This conference series strives to bring together the most prominent researchers in these fields, together with a large number of younger mathematicians, and bring about productive interactions in all directions. 

The Sixth Ahlfors-Bers Colloquium took place at Yale University on October 23-26, 2014. There were 10 plenary speakers and 39 parallel sessions featuring contributed talks. There were 124 registered participants, of whom 30 were graduate students and 46 postdoc/untenured faculty. 23 were women. Talks were extremely well-attended, and the schedule was also structured so as to give participants significant time periods for informal discussions.

The plenary talks outlined a number of exciting new developments and directions, including results on quasi-isometric rigidity, an area that connects group theory and coarse geometry of spaces, new analytical methods in the study of Teichmuller theory, recent breakthroughs in Thurston's program for the geometry and topology of 3-manifolds, new results in dynamical systems, and others.

As has been the tradition with these conferences, a Proceedings volume is currently being prepared.
